headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Severe Weather Ravaging the United States, as Parts of the Country Endure a Devastating Tornado Streak; Inside a Ghost Town in Iceland Near an Active Volcano; Paris 2024 Olympic Flame Arrives in France. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I just heard. It was a roar. That`s all it was, was a roar. And it`s gone. We have farm animals and we don`t know where nothing`sat. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: The severe weather also brought flash floods, which led to water rescues and blocked roads north of Nashville. So far, strong storms acrossthe central and southern U.S. have caused at least four deaths. This powerful tornado just pummeled Portage, Michigan earlier this week. You can see one tree toppled after the next. Luckily, no serious injuries reported in Portage. The Storm Prediction Center says April to June is the most active time for tornadoes in the U.S. and May is often the busiest month. In Brazil, more rain is expected today through Sunday. Torrential downpours have already caused catastrophic flooding in the southern part of the country, affecting more than one million people. Tens of thousands of people have been rescued. More than 100 have been killed. McKenna Ewen has more on the difficult times in Brazil. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MCKENNA EWEN, CNN DIGITAL PRODUCER
utterances.sentences: Video shows an airport tarmac in Rio Grande do Sul`s capital heavily flooded. This comes after heavy rains hitthe southern Brazilian state during the past week. The rains and consequent flooding in the region have caused a growing number of deaths and resulted in many missing. The region has been increasingly hit by extreme weather events in the past few years. The climate crisis caused by the burning of fossil fuels is making extreme weather events more intense and more frequent around the world. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Next, we head to Iceland, a country of fewer than 400,000 people. It`s home to 32 active volcanoes. Now, living near a volcano may soundscary, but for the folks in the small town of Grindavik, there hadn`t been an eruption for literally hundreds of years. But as you will see in this report from CNN`s Laura Paddison, that is no longer the case. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: LAURA PADDISON, CNN SENIOR CLIMATE WRITER
utterances.sentences: It`s incredibly deep.

utterances.speaker: KLARA HALLDORSDOTTIR, FORMER RESIDENT OF GRINDAVIK
utterances.sentences: It is incredibly deep. And there were huge cracks in that area, which they`ve filled up already.And this is actually the same crack that goes through town as well, all the way to the crater area, basically.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: And it`s actually perilously close to your house just there.

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: It is. Yeah.PADDISON (voice-over): This volcanic eruption just a few miles from the small town of Grindavik is the latest in a series of volcanic events to rock the Reykjanes Peninsula in southwest Iceland. Having laid dormant for eight centuries, the volcanic system here is reawakening, marking a new period of activity that could last tens or even hundreds of years. For Grindavik`s 3,600 residents, that means dealing with lava flows, powerful earthquakes, destructive fissures and evacuations. Klara Halldorsdottir and her family evacuated in November last year. And like many, she doesn`t plan to return. (FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: I was asking if he`s moved back, but he said, no, no, no, I`m not going to risk it.PADDISON (on camera): Is he just visiting then?

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: Picking up some stuff.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: And so no one is really living in this part?

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: No. Maybe there are about 30 people already living in Grindavik.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: But yeah, the rest of us aren`t that keen on that. And, you know, nobody knows what Mother Nature is going to do next.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: So did lots of houses around here get damaged when this happened, right? I guess the ground must have moved quite a lot.

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: It did, actually. The brown house, it`s completely ruined. And the black house here is sinking more and more. And the grey house is myhorse staple. And we used to keep our horses on this pasture. There are no pictures on the walls now, so it feels kind of like a house with no soul. For me and most of the people in Grindavik, having the eruptions in 2021 and the following years so close by, it was fascinating. The earthquakes, of course, were the downside of it. But then it happened so close to town. And that`s a totally different story.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: And can you tell me a bit about what the community was like here?

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: It`s a community of people who more or less know each other. And you would go to the grocery store and have a talk. And it waslike a close community. Now we`re spread out through various towns. And this is the feeling that we miss the most, I think.

utterances.speaker: PADDISON
utterances.sentences: Your kids, did they want to stay here or are they kind of --

utterances.speaker: HALLDORSDOTTIR
utterances.sentences: They still want to stay here. Yeah, it`s harder for them, definitely. This is where they grew up and they don`t know anything else.And now we`re cooped up in a small apartment. I think Icelanders are quite tough. I mean, we live in a harsh nature. And we`ve always known that this was an active area, but nothing has happened for 800 years. And the last time that there was an eruption so close to towns was in the Western Islands 51 years ago. It lasted for a few months, but then it was over. And then you could start rebuilding the community. But here we don`t know when it`s going to end. (END VIDEOTAPE)
